content.description:
Telegraph Crack starts with a small roof move and contains fingers to large hands moves between stances.

This climb looks like a pile from a distance, but is actually quite fun to climb with its mixture of jams. A fun moderate option.
content.protection: medium nuts - small/medium cams to 3". Rap anchor at top.
content.location: If you are headed up to the access gully on the East side of Snowshed (to access climbs like Nova Express, etc.), this climb will be the varied crack splitting a north-facing wall.

content.description:
Climb easy, featured corners 10 feet to the left of Telegraph Crack until a leftward traverse along a foot rail takes you to a small bulge. Pull over with crimps and seams and continue up the steep slab on small features. The crux comes after the lone bolt and involves a tenuous rockover to the left on minuscule crimps. Easy featured slab (dirty!!) to the top.

The Horniak guide shows a bolted anchor lower on the face, but we did not find it. Instead there are two very rusty cold shuts on the ledge at the top of the wall. I would recommend traversing right to use the better anchor for Telegraph Crack about 6 feet lower. The author also suggests 11c/d for the grade, but that seems like a hefty sandbag. Go up there expecting a 12- with spicy gear, friable footholds, and lots of lichen. In its current state, the route seemed like a harder onsight than Bell Bottom Blues.

With replaced anchors, a heavy cleaning, and--dare I suggest--another bolt or two, this route could become part of the typical Snowshed circuit.
content.protection: An emphasis on cams in the 0.1-0.4 range and offset nuts should see you through. Many of the placements are suboptimal, and there's usually a variety of dubious choices--a real engineering challenge. The crux bolt seems to be on the older side but held several falls (much better than the anchors at least).

content.description: Arete R of Mole's Corner. Start direct. Last moves feel a little airy, but safe. Good training for the gritsone!
content.protection:
green alien in break to protect the inital moves onto the slab proper, then 3 fixe SS 3/8x3.5" with SS hangers. Finish at Moles Corner anchor. Can sling the tree to protect the second on the final moves.

NO TR ANCHOR INSTALLED ON PURPOSE, PLEASE DONT ADD ONE, lets try to reinstate the OS/groundup ethos to NorCal!

climbs.name: Mole's Corner
climbs.fa: Tom Caramia, Gary Allan, Max Jones, 1976

content.description: A short but beautiful almost laser-cut corner with a small roof to finish.  This route would be classic if it was 2-3 times longer.
content.location: The obvious corner to the right of Telegraph Crack.
